Article:
124. Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court
 (1) There shall be a Supreme Court of India constituting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than seven other Judges
 (2) Every Judge of the Supreme Court shall be appointed by the President by warrant under his hand and seal after consultation with such of the Judges of the Supreme Court and of the High Courts in the States as the President may deem necessary for the purpose and shall hold office until he attains the age of sixty five years: Provided that in the case of appointment of a Judge other than the chief Justice, the chief Justice of India shall always be consulted:
 (a) a Judge may, by writing under his hand addressed to the President, resign his office;
 (b) a Judge may be removed rom his office in the manner provided in clause ( 4 )
2A. The age of a Judge of the Supreme Court shall be determined by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law provide
 (3) A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court unless he is a citizen of India and
 (a) has been for at least five years a Judge of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or
 (b) has been for at least ten years an advocate of a High Court or of two or more such Courts in succession; or
 (c) is, in the opinion of the President, a distinguished jurist Explanation I In this clause High Court means a High Court which exercises, or which at any time before the commencement of this Constitution exercised, jurisdiction in any part of the territory of India Explanation II In computing for the purpose of this clause the period during which a person has been an advocate, any period during which a person has held judicial office not inferior to that of a district judge after he became an advocate shall be included
 (4) A Judge of the Supreme Court shall not be removed from his office except by an order of the President passed after an address by each House of Parliament supported by a majority of the total membership of that House and by a majority of not less than two third of the members of the House present and voting has been presented to the President in the same session for such removal on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity
 (5) Parliament may by law regulate the procedure for the presentation of an address and for the investigation and proof of the misbehaviour or incapacity of a Judge under clause ( 4 ):
 (6) Every person appointed to be a Judge of the Supreme Court shall, before he enters upon his office, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule
 (7) No person who has held office as a Judge of the Supreme Court shall plead or act in any court or before any authority within the territory of India
Title: Article 124: Establishment and Constitution of the Supreme Court of India
Description:
This article outlines the establishment, constitution, and appointment procedures for the Supreme Court of India.

Clause 1: Establishment of the Supreme Court
Supreme Court: The highest judicial authority in India, which shall be established by the Constitution.
Composition:
The Chief Justice of India (CJI) is the head of the Supreme Court.
Until Parliament decides to increase the number, the Supreme Court will have no more than seven other judges, aside from the Chief Justice.
Clause 2: Appointment of Judges
The President of India appoints all Judges of the Supreme Court through a formal process.
The President consults with the Judges of the Supreme Court and High Courts before making the appointment, to ensure fairness and due process.
A Judge will hold office until the age of 65.
Consultation with CJI: For appointing a judge other than the Chief Justice, the Chief Justice of India must always be consulted.
A judge can resign by writing a resignation letter addressed to the President.
A judge can be removed from office under clause 4.
Clause 2A: Determining the Age of a Judge
Parliament may make a law to determine the age of a Supreme Court Judge through a specified authority and method.
Clause 3: Qualifications for Appointment
A person must meet one of the following criteria to be appointed as a Supreme Court Judge:

Judge of a High Court:

Must have served for at least five years as a judge in a High Court, or served as a judge in two or more High Courts in succession.
Advocate in a High Court:

Must have been an advocate for at least ten years in a High Court, or in two or more High Courts in succession.
Distinguished Jurist:

In the President’s opinion, the person must be a distinguished jurist, someone who has contributed notably to the field of law.
Explanation:

The term High Court includes any High Court that has exercised jurisdiction in any part of India's territory, even before the Constitution came into effect.
If a person has held a judicial office equivalent to that of a district judge after becoming an advocate, this period can be counted as part of the ten years of being an advocate.
Clause 4: Removal of Judges
A Supreme Court Judge cannot be removed from office unless:
An address is presented to the President by both Houses of Parliament.
The address must be supported by a majority of the total membership of each House.
Additionally, two-thirds of the members present and voting in both Houses must support the address.
The removal is based on proved misbehaviour or incapacity.
Clause 5: Regulation of Procedure
Parliament may make a law to regulate:
The procedure for presenting an address to the President for removal.
The procedure for investigating and proving misbehaviour or incapacity of a Judge.
Clause 6: Oath or Affirmation
Before starting their duties, every appointed Supreme Court Judge must take an oath or affirmation before the President or someone appointed by the President.
The oath is according to the form specified in the Third Schedule of the Constitution.
Clause 7: Restrictions After Retirement
A person who has served as a Judge of the Supreme Court cannot plead or act in any court or before any authority within India once they retire. This is to ensure independence and impartiality of the judiciary.

Article:
125. Salaries, etc, of Judges
 (1) There shall be paid to the Judges of the Supreme Court such salaries as may be determined by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries as are specified in the Second Schedule
 (2) Every Judge shall be entitled to such privileges and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as may from time to time be determined by or under law made by Parliament and, until so determined, to such privileges, allowances and rights as are specified in the Second Schedule: Provided that neither the privileges nor the allowances of a Judge nor his rights in respect of leave of absence or pension shall be varied to his disadvantage after his appointment
Title: Article 125 - Salaries, etc, of Judges
Description:
This article talks about the salaries and benefits of judges in the Supreme Court.

The government will pay judges a salary, which is decided by Parliament.
The judges will also get certain privileges, allowances, and benefits like leave and pension, which Parliament decides.
Once a judge is appointed, their benefits can’t be reduced. They cannot lose any privileges after becoming a judge.

Article: 126. Appointment of acting Chief Justice When the office of Chief Justice of India is vacant or when the Chief Justice is, by reason or absence or otherwise, unable to perform the duties of his office, the duties of the office shall be performed by such one of the other Judges of the Court as the President may appoint for the purpose
Title: Article 126 - Appointment of Acting Chief Justice
Description: When the Chief Justice of India is not available (maybe because they’re absent or the position is vacant), the President can appoint another judge from the Supreme Court to do the Chief Justice’s job temporarily.

Article:
127. Appointment of ad hoc Judges
 (1) If at any time there should not be a quorum of the Judges of the Supreme Court available to hold or continue any session of the Court, the Chief Justice of India may, with the previous consent of the President and after consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court concerned, request in writing the attendance at the sittings of the Court, as an ad hoc Judge, for such period as may be necessary, of a Judge of a High Court duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court to be designated by the Chief Justice of India
 (2) It shall be the duty of the Judge who has been so designated, in priority to other duties of his office, to attend the sittings of the Supreme Court at the time and for the period for which his attendance is required, and while so attending he shall have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges, and shall discharge the duties, of a Judge of the Supreme Court
Title: Article 127 - Appointment of ad hoc Judges
Description:
Sometimes, there may not be enough judges in the Supreme Court to continue a case.

In such situations, the Chief Justice can ask a judge from a High Court (who qualifies to be a Supreme Court judge) to temporarily join the Supreme Court as an ad hoc judge to help out.
The judge will prioritize this job and have the same powers as any other Supreme Court judge while doing this work.

Article: 128. Attendance of retired Judges at sittings of the Supreme Court Notwithstanding anything in this chapter, the Chief Justice of India may at any time, with the previous consent of the president, request any person who has held the office of a Judge of the Supreme Court or of the Federal Court or who has held the office of a Judge of a High Court and is duly qualified for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court to sit and act as a Judge of the Supreme Court, and every such person so requested shall, while so sitting and acting, be entitled to such allowances as the President may by order determine and have all the jurisdiction, powers and privileges of, but shall not otherwise be deemed to be, a Judge of that Court: Provided that nothing in this article shall be deemed to require any such person as aforesaid to sit and act as a Judge of that Court unless he consents so to do
Title: Article 128 - Attendance of Retired Judges at Sittings of the Supreme Court
Description:
This article allows retired judges to come back and help the Supreme Court if needed.

The Chief Justice can ask a retired judge to sit in the Supreme Court, with the President’s approval.
The retired judge will have the same powers as a regular judge but will not be considered a permanent judge unless they agree to help.

Article: 129. Supreme Court to be a court of record The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself
Title: Article 129 - Supreme Court to be a Court of Record
Description:
The Supreme Court is an important court, and it keeps a record of all its decisions and actions.

This means it has the power to store records, and it can punish anyone who disrespects or doesn't follow its orders (contempt of court).

Article: 130. Seat of Supreme Court The Supreme Court shall sit in Delhi or in such other place or places, as the Chief Justice of India may, with the approval of the President, from time to time, appoint
Title: Article 130 - Seat of Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court usually sits in Delhi, but the Chief Justice can decide to hold court in another place if needed, with the President’s approval.

Article:
131. Original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, the Supreme Court shall, to the exclusion of any other court, have original jurisdiction in any dispute
 (a) between the Government of India and one or more States; or
 (b) between the Government of India and any State or States on one side and one or more other States on the other; or
 (c) between two or more States, if and in so far as the dispute involves any question (whether of law or fact) on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends: Provided that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to a dispute arising out of any treaty, agreement, covenant, engagements, and or other similar instrument which, having been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution, continues in operation after such commencement, or which provides that the said jurisdiction shall not extend to such a dispute
Title: Article 131 - Original Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Description:
The Supreme Court has the power to hear certain types of cases first (before any other court). These cases can be:

Disagreements between the Government of India and one or more states.
Disagreements between different states.
The Supreme Court decides such cases if they are about legal rights.
But, if the case is related to old agreements or treaties made before the Constitution started, the Supreme Court won’t handle it.

Article:
132. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in certain cases ( 1 ) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order of a High Court in the territory of India, whether in a civil, criminal or other proceeding, if the High Court certifies under Article 134A that the case involves a substantial question of law as t the interpretation of this Constitution
 (2) Omitted
 (3) Where such a certificate is given, any party in the case may appeal to the Supreme Court on the ground that any such question as aforesaid has been wrongly decided Explanation For the purposes of this article, the expression final order includes an order declaring an issue which, if decided in favour of the appellant, would be sufficient for the final disposal of the case
Title: Article 132 - Appellate Jurisdiction of Supreme Court in Appeals from High Courts in Certain Cases
Description:
This article allows people to appeal to the Supreme Court if they think the High Court made a mistake in a big legal question about the Constitution.

If the High Court says the case involves a big legal question, anyone involved in the case can appeal to the Supreme Court.

Article:
133. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in appeals from High Courts in regard to civil matters
 (1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, decree or final order in a civil proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court certifies under Article 134A
 (a) that the case involves a substantial question of law of general importance; and
 (b) that in the opinion of the High Court the said question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court
 (2) Notwithstanding anything in Article 132, any party appealing to the Supreme Court under clause ( 1 ) may urge as one of the grounds in such appeal that a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution has been wrongly decided
 (3) Notwithstanding anything in this article, no appeal shall, unless Parliament by law otherwise provides, lie to the Supreme Court from the judgment, decree or final order of one Judge of a High Court
Title: Article 133: Appellate Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court in Civil Matters from High Courts
Description:
This article defines the procedure and conditions under which an appeal can be made to the Supreme Court of India from the High Courts in civil matters.

Clause 1: Appeal to the Supreme Court
An appeal can be made to the Supreme Court from a High Court's judgment, decree, or final order in a civil case, but only under the following conditions:

The High Court certifies the case under Article 134A:
Substantial Question of Law: The case must involve a substantial question of law of general importance. This means the legal issue is significant enough that it should be settled at the national level.
Need for Supreme Court Decision: The High Court must be of the opinion that this question needs to be decided by the Supreme Court. It indicates that the issue is important enough to require a final decision from the highest court.
Clause 2: Grounds for Appeal
Even if an appeal is made under Clause 1, the appellant (the person appealing) may also argue that:

A substantial question of law concerning the interpretation of the Constitution has been wrongly decided by the High Court. This provides the appellant the opportunity to challenge the High Court’s interpretation of constitutional matters.
Clause 3: Restrictions on Appeals from Single Judge of a High Court
No Appeal from a Single Judge: Generally, no appeal shall be made to the Supreme Court from the judgment, decree, or final order of a single judge of a High Court, unless Parliament makes a law allowing it.
This ensures that appeals from a single judge's decision of a High Court are limited, and the appeal process is typically reserved for decisions made by a larger bench of the High Court (a bench with more than one judge).

Article:
134. Appellate jurisdiction of Supreme Court in regard to criminal matters
 (1) An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India if the High Court has on appeal reversed an order of acquittal of an accused person and sentenced him to death; or has withdrawn for trial before itself any case from any court subordinate to its authority and has in such trial convicted the accused person and sentenced him to death; or
 (c) certifies under Article 134A that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court: Provided that an appeal under sub clause (c) shall lie subject to such provisions as may be made in that behalf under clause ( 1 ) of Article 145 and to such conditions as the High Court may establish or require
 (2) Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court any further powers to entertain and hear appeals from any judgment, final order or sentence in a criminal proceeding of a High Court in the territory of India subject to such conditions and limitations as may be specified in such law
134A. Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court Every High Court, passing or making a judgment, decree, final order, or sentence, referred to in clause ( 1 ) of Article 132 or clause ( 1 ) of Article 133, or clause ( 1 ) of Article 134
 (a) may, if it deems fit so to do, on its own motion; and
 (b) shall, if an oral application is made, by or on behalf of the party aggrieved, immediately after the passing or making of such judgment, decree, final order or sentence, determine, as soon as may be after such passing or making, the question whether a certificate of the nature referred to in clause ( 1 ) of Article 132, or clause ( 1 ) of Article 133 or, as the case may be, sub clause (c) of clause ( 1 ) of Article 134, may be given in respect of that case
Title: Article 134 - Appellate Jurisdiction of Supreme Court in Criminal Matters and Certificate for appeal to the Supreme Court
Description:
This article talks about criminal cases (cases where someone is accused of breaking the law).

People can appeal to the Supreme Court if the High Court:
Changes a judgment and sentences someone to death.
Takes a case from a lower court and sentences someone to death.
The Supreme Court will also hear appeals if the High Court says the case is important and needs the Supreme Court’s attention.
Parliament can also make laws to give the Supreme Court more power in hearing criminal appeals.

When a High Court makes an important decision, it can give a ""certificate"" saying that the case is important enough to be appealed in the Supreme Court.
If a person wants to appeal, they can ask the High Court for this certificate right after the decision is made, and the High Court will decide whether to give it.

Article: 135. Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court Until Parliament by law otherwise provides, the Supreme Court shall also have jurisdiction and powers with respect to any matter to which the provisions of Article 133 or Article 134 do not apply if jurisdiction and powers in relation to that matter were exercisable by the Federal Court immediately before the commencement of this Constitution under any existing law
Title: Article 135 - Jurisdiction and powers of the Federal Court under existing law to be exercisable by the Supreme Court
Description: Before India’s Constitution, there was a Federal Court. If a case wasn't covered by the Articles about High Courts, the Federal Court could handle it. After the Constitution, the Supreme Court can take on those responsibilities.

Article:
136. Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
 (1) Notwithstanding anything in this Chapter, the Supreme Court may, in its discretion, grant special leave to appeal from any judgment, decree, determination, sentence or order in any cause or matter passed or made by any court or tribunal in the territory of India
 (2) Nothing in clause ( 1 ) shall apply to any judgment, determination, sentence or order passed or made by any court or tribunal constituted by or under any law relating to the Armed Forces
Title: Article 136 - Special leave to appeal by the Supreme Court
Description:
The Supreme Court has the power to allow someone to appeal to it from any court in India, even if the law doesn’t automatically allow it. This is called "special leave" and is given at the Supreme Court's discretion.
However, this does not apply to cases involving the Armed Forces.

Article: 137. Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under Article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it
Title: Article 137 - Review of judgments or orders by the Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court can review its own decisions. If it made a mistake, it can correct it. The Parliament might also make rules about how the Court can do this.

Article:
138. Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
 (1) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction and powers with respect to any of the matters in the Union List as Parliament may by law confer
 (2) The Supreme Court shall have such further jurisdiction, and powers with respect to any matter as the Government of India and the Government of any State may by special agreement confer, if Parliament by law provides for the exercise of such jurisdiction and powers by the Supreme Court
Title: Article 138 - Enlargement of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court
Description: The Supreme Court’s powers can be expanded by Parliament. If Parliament decides that the Supreme Court should handle more types of cases, it can give the Court extra authority.

Article:
139. Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs Parliament may by law confer on the Supreme Court power to issue directions, orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for any purposes other than those mentioned in clause ( 2 ) of Article 32
139A. Transfer of certain cases
 (1) Where cases involving the same or substantially the same questions of law are pending before the Supreme Court and one or more High Courts or before two or more High Courts and the Supreme Court is satisfied on its own motion or an application made by the Attorney General of India or by a party to any such case that such questions are substantial questions of general importance, the Supreme Court may withdraw the case or cases pending before the High Court or the High Courts and dispose of all the cases itself: Provided that the Supreme Court may after determining the said questions of law return any case so withdrawn together with a copy of its judgment on such questions to the High Court from which the case has been withdrawn, and the High Court shall on receipt thereof, proceed to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment
 (2) The Supreme Court may, if it deems it expedient so to do for the ends of justice, transfer any case, appeal or other proceedings pending before any High Court to any other High Court
Title: Article 139 - Conferment on the Supreme Court of powers to issue certain writs and Transfer of certain cases
Description:
Parliament can give the Supreme Court the power to issue orders or ""writs"" like habeas corpus, mandamus, and others. These orders are used to protect people’s rights and ensure justice."
If there are multiple cases about the same legal question, the Supreme Court can take them all and decide the issue. If needed, the Supreme Court can also move cases from one High Court to another for easier justice.
Parliament can give the Supreme Court the power to issue orders or "writs" like habeas corpus, mandamus, and others. These orders are used to protect people’s rights and ensure justice.

Article: 140. Ancillary powers of Supreme Court Parliament may by law make provision for conferring upon the Supreme Court such supplemental powers not inconsistent with any of the provisions of this Constitution as may appear to be necessary or desirable for the purpose of enabling the Court more effectively to exercise the jurisdiction conferred upon it by or under this Constitution
Title: Article 140 - Ancillary powers of Supreme Court
Description: Parliament can give the Supreme Court additional powers if needed to help it do its job better, as long as those powers don't conflict with the Constitution.

Article: 141. Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts The law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India
Title: Article 141 - Law declared by Supreme Court to be binding on all courts
Description: Any decision made by the Supreme Court on a law must be followed by all other courts in India. This ensures that the law is applied the same way everywhere.

Article:
142. Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court and unless as to discovery, etc ( 1 ) The Supreme Court in the exercise of its jurisdiction may pass such decree or make such order as is necessary for doing complete justice in any cause or matter pending before it, and any decree so passed or orders so made shall be enforceable throughout the territory of India in such manner as may be prescribed by or under any law made by Parliament and, until provision in that behalf is so made, in such manner as the President may by order prescribe
 (2) Subject to the provisions of any law made in this behalf by Parliament, the Supreme Court shall, as respects the whole of the territory of India, have all and every power to make any order for the purpose of securing the attendance of any person, the discovery or production of any documents, or the investigation or punishment of any contempt of itself
Title: Article 142 - Enforcement of decrees and orders of Supreme Court
Description: If the Supreme Court makes a decision, it can issue orders that must be followed across India. The President can also make sure the orders are followed. The Supreme Court can even make orders to force people to attend court, produce documents, or punish those who disrespect the Court.

Article:
143. Power of President to consult Supreme Court ( 1 ) If at any time it appears to the President that a question of law or fact has arisen, or is likely to arise, which is of such a nature and of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the opinion of the Supreme Court upon it, he may refer the question to that Court for consideration and the Court may, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon
 (2) The President may, notwithstanding anything in the proviso to Article 131, refer a dispute of the kind mentioned in the said proviso to the Supreme Court for opinion and the Supreme Court shall, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report to the President its opinion thereon
Title: Article 143 - Power of President to consult Supreme Court
Description:
If the President thinks a question of law is very important and needs clarity, they can ask the Supreme Court for its opinion. The Supreme Court will consider the issue and give its opinion.
The President can also ask the Supreme Court about disputes between states and the central government.

Article: 144. Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court All authorities, civil and judicial, in the territory of India shall act in aid of the Supreme Court
Title: Article 144 - Civil and judicial authorities to act in aid of the Supreme Court
Description: All government authorities and courts in India must help the Supreme Court in its work. This ensures that the Supreme Court’s orders are carried out.

Title: Article 145: Rules of Court, etc.
Description:
This article grants the Supreme Court the authority to establish its own rules of practice and procedure, subject to the laws made by Parliament and with the approval of the President.

Key Provisions of Article 145:
Supreme Court's Power to Make Rules (Clause 1):

The Supreme Court can create rules to regulate the practice and procedure of the Court. This includes a wide range of matters, such as:
Rules for practitioners: The Court can set rules for the individuals or entities who may practice before it.
Appeals procedure: It can create rules for hearing appeals, including the time limits within which appeals must be filed.
Enforcement of rights: The Court can establish rules regarding proceedings to enforce rights granted by Part III of the Constitution (Fundamental Rights).
Article 139A procedures: Rules can be made for proceedings under Article 139A (transfer of cases to the Supreme Court).
Appeals under Article 134: The Court can create rules for entertaining appeals under specific provisions of Article 134 (regarding appeals in criminal matters).
Review of judgments: The Court can establish procedures for reviewing its own judgments or orders, including the time within which review applications must be filed.
Costs and fees: Rules regarding the costs involved in any proceedings and the fees that should be charged for those proceedings.
Bail: Rules for the granting of bail in cases heard by the Supreme Court.
Stay of proceedings: Rules concerning the stay of proceedings.
Frivolous appeals: Rules allowing the summary dismissal of frivolous or vexatious appeals.
Inquiries under Article 317: The Court can regulate the procedure for inquiries referred to in Article 317 (related to removal of certain public servants).
Minimum Number of Judges for Certain Cases (Clause 2 and 3):

Clause 2: The Supreme Court rules may fix the minimum number of judges required to hear a case or perform a function. It can also provide for the powers of single judges or division benches (a bench with more than one judge).
Clause 3: For cases involving substantial constitutional questions, a minimum of five judges must hear the case. This also applies to references made under Article 143.
However, if a smaller bench (less than five judges) hears a case and finds a substantial constitutional question that must be addressed, the bench must refer the issue to a larger bench (five judges or more). Once the larger bench delivers its opinion, the smaller bench will dispose of the case based on that opinion.
Judgment Delivery (Clause 4):

Open Court Delivery: The Supreme Court must deliver its judgments in open court. This ensures transparency and accountability in the judicial process.
Article 143 Opinion: Similarly, any report or opinion under Article 143 (which involves the President seeking advice from the Supreme Court on legal matters) must also be delivered in open court.
Majority for Judgment (Clause 5):

For any judgment or opinion to be delivered, it must have the concurrence of the majority of the judges present in the hearing.
However, a judge who does not agree with the majority can still deliver a dissenting judgment or opinion.

Article:
146. Officers and servants and the expenses of the Supreme Court
 (1) Appointments of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be made by the Chief Justice of India or such other Judge or officer of the Court as he may direct: Provided that the President may by rule require that in such cases as may be specified in the rule, no person not already attached to the Court shall be appointed to any office connected with the Court, save after consultation with the Union Public Service Commission
 (2) Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament, the conditions of service of officers and servants of the Supreme Court shall be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of India or by some other Judge or officer of the Court authorised by the Chief Justice of India to make rules for the purpose: Provided that the rules made under this clause shall, so far as they relate to salaries, allowances, leave or pensions, require the approval of the President
 (3) The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court, including all salaries, allowances and pensions payable to or in respect of the offices and servants of the Court, shall be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India, and any fees or other moneys taken by the court shall form part of that Fund
Title: Article 146: Officers and Servants and the Expenses of the Supreme Court
Description:
This article outlines the provisions related to the appointments, conditions of service, and expenses of the officers and servants working in the Supreme Court of India.

Key Provisions of Article 146:
Appointments of Officers and Servants (Clause 1):

Appointments for officers and servants of the Supreme Court will be made by the Chief Justice of India (CJI) or by another judge or officer as directed by the CJI.
Consultation with the Union Public Service Commission (UPSC):
The President of India can issue rules requiring that in certain cases, no person who is not already attached to the Supreme Court should be appointed to any office connected with the Court, unless consulted with the UPSC.
Conditions of Service (Clause 2):

The conditions of service (such as work duties, roles, and responsibilities) for officers and servants will be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice of India or a designated officer/judge authorized by the CJI.
However, if these rules relate to salaries, allowances, leave, or pensions, they require the approval of the President of India.
Administrative Expenses (Clause 3):

The administrative expenses of the Supreme Court (including salaries, allowances, and pensions for officers and servants) are to be charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India.
Any fees or other money collected by the Court will also become part of the Consolidated Fund of India

Article: 147. Interpretation In this Chapter and in Chapter V of Part VI references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution shall be construed as including references to any substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Government of India Act, 1935 (including any enactment amending or supplementing that Act), or of any Order in Council or order made thereunder, or of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 , or of any order made thereunder CHAPTER V COMPTROLLER AND AUDITOR GENERAL OF INDIA
Title: Article 147: Interpretation
Description: This article is about how to interpret certain laws or constitutional questions. If there’s any doubt about how to understand the Constitution or older laws like the Government of India Act of 1935, it should be treated as a big question about the Constitution.
